conclusion: Determine how shadows A, B, C, and D change when the light source moves forward above the objects.
Position and size of a shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface.
Four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
Light source is positioned above and slightly behind the objects, causing shadows to extend forward.
When the light source moves forward, it gets closer to being directly above the objects.
As the light source moves forward, the angle of the light rays hitting the objects changes.
As the light source moves forward, shadows will move backward (toward the objects) because the angle of incidence becomes more vertical.
Shadows will shift in the direction opposite to the movement of the light source.
The closer the light source is to being directly above the objects, the shorter the shadows will become.
As the light source moves forward and gets closer to a vertical position, the shadows will decrease in length.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward (toward the objects) on the ground.
Shadows will become shorter as the light source moves forward.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward and become shorter as the light source moves forward.
